column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Make a Pinhole Viewer
#Text=Out of a Coffee Can
#Text=Viewing an eclipse can be both exciting and fun but there is a hazard with damage to your eyes if you 're not cautious with your method of viewing .
#Text=This pinhole viewer is a great way to view an eclipse without having to look directly at the sun , and it 's easy to make with a coffee can or similar cylindrical box .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Get your container ready .
#Text=On the bottom of the container , make a hole in the center .
#Text=Placing the pin hole in the exact center is not necessary .
#Text=The viewer will work as long as the hole is placed somewhere in the center area .
#Text=Placing it in the exact center simply looks nicer and will , of course , project the image on the center of the viewer section .
#Text=To
#Text=If another box , like a cardboard oatmeal container , is used , be careful in handling since it will not be as durable as the coffee container .
#Text=To determine the center , use the ruler to measure and mark the top and bottom fourths of the container .
#Text=Use a marker to mark two lines on the upper and lower sections of the metal portion of the coffee can .
#Text=Use a pencil to gently mark these lines if using the oatmeal container .
#Text=Use the ruler to join the ends of the lines together creating an " X " pattern .
#Text=The center of the " X " will mark the center of container .
#Text=This is where the hole will be pierced .
#Text=Use a push pin or small nail to push it through the center of the " X " .
#Text=This will allow enough light to project an image of the sun .
#Text=The size of the hole should not be larger than the width of a push pin or paper clip .
#Text=If you no longer want the lines on the container after the hole is pierced , erase the lines on a cardboard viewer .
#Text=On the metal coffee can bottom , use a tissue and small amount of rubbing alcohol to clean and remove the lines .
#Text=Carefully grab the blade or craft knife .
#Text=Lay the plastic lid on an old magazine or pile of newspapers to protect your table and cut away the center of the lid .
#Text=Leave an eighth to quarter inch border from the cut to the edge of the line .
#Text=Place the lid on the corner of a sheet of white paper .
#Text=Draw around the outer portion of the lid .
#Text=This will serve as your guide line as you cut out the circle .
#Text=Placing it on the corner of the paper will make it easier to cut the paper into a disc .
#Text=Cut out the circle to create a small disc .
#Text=At first , the disc will not fit into the plastic lid .
#Text=Continue to trim the disk until it fits inside the lid .
#Text=The disc does not have to fit snugly .
#Text=It should lay flat without being pushed up by the edge of the lid .
#Text=This paper will serve as the viewing screen .
#Text=Place the lid with the paper disc inserted on the table .
#Text=Take the can and and fit open end onto the lid .
#Text=The disc should be held firmly in place by the can .
#Text=The lid will anchor the paper , creating the screen for the viewer .
#Text=Use the viewer .
#Text=Hold it at an angle away from you .
#Text=Point the pin hole side of the viewer toward the sun .
#Text=You should be able to look at the screen of the viewer without looking at the sun .
#Text=Keep adjusting your angle until you can see a small projection of the sun on the paper disc .
#Text=As the eclipse progresses , you will see the small dot of light began to disappear as either completely or partially depending on .
#Text=Warnings
#Text=Always hold the viewer at an angle away from you and do not look directly at the sun .
#Text=Serious damage could occur to your eyes if looking directly at the sun for even a few seconds .
#Text=Things You 'll Need
#Text=Coffee can or similar round box ( eg an oatmeal box )
#Text=Marker
#Text=Scissors
#Text=Craft knife or blade
#Text=Ruler
#Text=White sheet of paper
#Text=Push pin or small nail
#Text=Old magazine or newspaper ( for use with blade )
